# Replication Package for Article "Difference Verification with Conditions", SEFM '20

This replication package supports reproducing the claims of the SEFM 2020 publication
"D. Beyer, M.-C. Jakobs, and T. Lemberger: Difference Verification with Conditions".

Difference verification with conditions is an incremental program
verification technique that can be integrated in software projects at any time.
It first applies a change analysis that detects which parts of a sof...

Please refer to the README.md file located in the same directory for instructions on how to reproduce our results from the paper and how t...

name: Issues in Compiling
description: We consider the state of the art in compiler construction and where to go from here. Main topics are improved exploitation of present (and future) hardware features, the interaction between compiling techniques and processor design, and the use of compiling techniques in application areas such as component-based software engineering and software reengineering.

name: An open architecture control system for multi‐axis wood CNC machining center
description:
Abstract:

This paper presents an open architecture control system for multi‐axis wood computer numerical control (CNC) milling machining centre, based on LinuxCNC. The wood CNC machining system is supported by an equivalent virtual machine in a CAD/CAM environment, as well as in the control system. Simulation within virtual environment is essential for multi‐axis machining, and the developed virtual machines are used for program verification and monitoring of the machining process. The virtu...

name: ForEx: Automated Software Verification of Hyperliveness
description:
This is the accompanying artifact for

Raven Beutner. Automated Software Verification of Hyperliveness. International Conference on Tools and Algorithms for the Construction and Analysis of Systems (TACAS) 2024.

The artifact contains the tool ForEx, a verifier for hyperliveness properties.
Note: This artifact is designed to run (and only run) in this VM. For instructions on how to install the latest version of ForEx on your machine visit github.com/ravenbeutner/ForEx.

The paper presents an approach that enhances difference verification with conditions. Difference verification with conditions is a regression verific...

name: Reproduction Package (Virtual Machine) for CAV 2020 Article `MetaVal: Witness Validation via Verification'
description:
The virtual machine (VM) is configured to use 2 CPU cores and 10 GB of RAM.
Both values can be lowered in case the host system does not provide these resources.
The memory was chosen to be 10 GB in order to guarantee
that at least 7 GB are available to MetaVal in order to be consistent with the resource limits
that seem to be standard in the community and are used by SV-COMP.

The VM was created with VirtualBox in version 5.2.34 and tested on a host machine
with an i5-7440HQ CPU and 31 GB of ...

Hardware Requirements

Minimal: - 8 GB of RAM - 1 CPU core - 20 GB of disk space

The README.md details how resource limits for the experiments ca...

name: Artifact - Gillian, Part II: Real-World Verification for JavaScript and C
description: We introduce compositional symbolic execution and verification based on separation logic to Gillian, a multi-language platform for the development of symbolic analysis tools. Our work develops a methodology for constructing compositional memory models for Gillian, leading to a unified presentation of the JavaScript and C memory models. We verify the JavaScript and C implementations of the Amazon AWS Encryption SDK message header deserialisation module, specifically designing common abstractio...

name: A Calculus for Modular Loop Acceleration - Artifact Evaluation
description: artifact associated with the TACAS '20 paper "A Calculus for Modular Loop Acceleration"
keywords: loop acceleration, software verification, formal methods

name: Applying the SCR Requirements Method to the Light Control Case Study
description: To date, the SCR (Software Cost Reduction) requirements method has been used in industrial environments to specify the requirements of many practical systems, including control systems for nuclear power plants and avionics systems. This paper describes the use of the SCR method to specify the requirements of the Light Control System (LCS), the subject of a case study at the Dagstuhl Seminar on Requirements Capture, Documentation, and Validation in June 1999. It introduces a systematic process...

name: Formal Verification and Design of Smart Stick for Blind People
description: Researchers these days widely use formal verification to verify software and embedded systems. This paper is based on a smart stick (embedded system) designed for blind people. This embedded system design has been verified using model checking and formal verification. In this paper, an Arduino based stick has been proposed for blind users to help in their navigation by detecting the obstacles using Ultrasonic sensors and speech warning message. It is able to inform the blind person about the ...
keywords: Assurance Technologies, blind navigation system, embedded systems, formal modeling, software verification

name: Ten Years of Historical Development "Bootstrapping" VDMTools
description: This article provides a historical overview of a decade of the development of the IFAD VDM Toolboxes commonly referred to as VDMTools. All along, the existing tools have been used in the development of new major components. This kind of "bootstrapping " approach where a CASE tool is developed by taking ""its own medicine" is seldom used. However, we believe that this approach is important to be able to better understand what the most important improvements are for the users in practice. This ...

name: HW-SW Co-verification of Concurrent Programs
description: In the ever-developing world of technology, more and more situations arise where the life of many people lay in the hands of computers - be it the processor of a self-driving car or an airplane, or the command center of a nuclear reactor. The most important expectation of critical software is that they should never fail in a way that could have been prevented. As there have already been many accounts of catastrophes that were caused by malfunctioning computers or programs, we need to verify t...

This is the replication package for the paper "FRed: Conditional Model Checking via Reducers and Folders" written by Dirk Beyer and Marie-Christine Jakobs. The paper is published in the proceedings of SEFM 2020.

The replication package is structured as follows:

BASE                                   # the base fol...

  in order to vi...

name: AutoCorres 1.0
description:
AutoCorres is a tool for use with the Isabelle/HOL interactive theorem prover that attempts to simplify the verification of software programs written in the C programming language. In particular, it takes the output of Michael Norrish's C-to-Isabelle parser and abstracts it into a logical representation intended to be easier to manually verify properties about. This version of AutoCorres works with the Isabelle 2014 distribution.

The following papers are based on the work in this to...

name: QuAC – Quantifying Software Correctness Using Architecture Modeling and Formal Program Analysis
description:
Most formal methods see the correctness of a software system as a yes-no decision. However, the provable correctness of complex systems is limited because they are composed of multiple components, usage scenarios, and environments.

We present QuAC (“Quantifying Architecture and Code”), a modular approach for quantifying the error probability in service-oriented software systems by combining software architecture modeling with deductive verification. Our approach is based on a mod...

name: Stateless software model checking parameterized with memory consistency models
description: Formal verification of multithreaded software running on multi-core hardware has for long been challenging for anything other than the simplest of programs. The complexity of dealing with the arbitrary interleavings of such a program makes it one of the hardest problems of software verification. However, the industry trend of introducing embedded multi-core processors into the world of safety critical systems makes it unavoidable having to deal with this problem, because formal methods are ev...

name: C for Yourself: Comparison of Front-End Techniques for Formal Verification (Artifact Submission)
description:
This artifact serves to make the experimental evaluation of the paper "C for Yourself: Comparison of Front-End Techniques for Formal Verification" reproducible. It contains a virtual machine with all the necessary binaries of the tools and the benchmarking framework to rerun the benchmarks that were executed. It also contains the source code of the tools, should someone need to rebuild it.

A few other configurations were also added: a really short smoke test to test if there are an...

name: Artifact Package: the Metis File System Model Checking Framework
description: Artifact package for the USENIX FAST 2024 paper: "Metis: File System Model Checking via Versatile Input and State Exploration".

name: Reproduction Package for FSE 2025 Submission `A Modular Program-Transformation Framework for Reducing Specifications to Reachability'
description:
This is the Artifact for the paper “A Modular Program-Transformation Framework for Reducing Specifications to Reachability” which has been submitted to FSE 2025.
The FSE article presents a program transformation framework with the goal of verifying different properties with of-the-shelf reachability analyzers. The transformations in a framework is based on instrumentation automata, inspired by the BLAST query language. In our initial study, we support three important concrete spec...

name: Systematic Evaluation and Usability Analysis of Formal Tools for Railway System Design - Technical Annexes
description:
This package includes additional data for the paper ``Systematic Evaluation and Usability Analysis of Formal Methods Tools for Railway Signalig System Design'', by Alessio Ferrari, Franco Mazzanti, Davide Basile, and Maurice ter Beek, CNR-ISTI, Italy, accepted for publication in the IEEE Transactions on Software Engineering, DOI: 10.1109/TSE.2021.3124677

The paper concerns the systematic evaluation and usability analysis of 14 formal tools for system design, ...

name: Evaluation Data of the Combined Approach
description:
This dataset contains the programs on which the Combined Approach was evaluated.

The Java source code of each evaluated program is in the "src" folder.
The compiled jar file of each evaluated program is in the "testdata" folder.

The .joak file contains the annotated sources and sinks for each evaluated program.
Note that you may not be able to load the .joak files directly into the Combined 
Approach program as the various paths in the .joak files need to be fixed f...

name: Reproduction Package (VM Version) for ICSE 2022 Article `Decomposing Software Verification into Off-the-Shelf Components: An Application to CEGAR'
description:
Decomposing Software Verification into Off-the-Shelf Components: An Application to CEGAR

Abstract: Tools for software verification are typically cohesive units of software with tightly coupled components. This makes it difficult to re-use components, and the potential for workload distribution is limited. Innovations in software verification might find their way into practice faster if provided in smaller, more specialized components.

In this paper, we propose to strictly decompose software...

name: Replication Package for article "Reusing Predicate Precision in Value Analysis"
description:
This artifact provides the replication package for the article

Marie-Christine Jakobs, Technische Universität Darmstadt, Department of Computer Science, Germany
Reusing Predicate Precision in Value Analysis
In Proceedings of 17th International Conference on integrated Formal Methods (iFM), Springer, 2022.

The paper discusses how to exchange information between predicate and value analysis, two abstraction-based software verification approaches. More concretely, it suggests 13 different...

name: Verification and validation of embedded software in an automotive context: a systematic literature review
description: In automotive context, the embedded software Verification and Validation (V&V) is always a critical step for each project that involves testing solutions for new function, system optimization and compliance with legal requirements. However, automotive software V&V is laborious and time-consuming. Activities such as planning workshops at test tracks and public roads and functionality and durability tests require significant effort and robust coordination. The rigorous management and st...

name: Model Checking for Abstract State Machines
description: In this paper, we discuss the use of a model checker in combination with the specification method of Abstract State Machines (ASMs). A schema is introduced for transforming ASM models into the language of a model checker. We prove that the transformation preserves the semantics of ASMs and provide a theoretical framework for a transformation tool. Experience with model-checking the ASM model of the Production Cell demonstrates that this approach offers effective support for verifying ASM spec...

name: Finding Software Vulnerabilities in Large C Projects via Bounded Model Checking
description: A novel verification approach that combines input-code analysis and BMC techniques to detect software vulnerabilities and assess findings in a detailed and user-friendly report. This approach can systematically guide a bounded model checker to verify large open-source software systems.Computer-based systems have solved several domain problems, including industrial, military, education, and wearable. Nevertheless, such arrangements need high-quality software to guarantee security and safe...

name: A Model Checker for Operator Precedence Languages
description: This paper presents a model checker, named POMC, for Operator Precedence Language (OPL) programs to prove properties expressed in Precedence Oriented Temporal Logic (POTL). To the best of the authors’ knowledge, POMC is the first implemented and openly available model checker for proving tree-structured properties of recursive procedural programs. They also report on the experimental evaluation they performed on POMC on a nontrivial benchmark.

name: Model-Checking Structured Context-Free Languages (Artifact)
description:
This is the artifact related to the article

M. Chiari, D. Mandrioli, M. Pradella: "Model-Checking Structured Context-Free Languages"

accepted at CAV 2021.

Abstract:


The problem of model checking procedural programs has fostered much research towards the definition of  temporal logics for reasoning on context-free structures. The most notable of such results are temporal logics on Nested Words, such as CaRet and NWTL.
Recently, the logic OPTL was introduced, based on the cl...

name: Artifact for the CAV'23 tool paper "Kratos2: an SMT-Based Model Checker for Imperative Programs"
description:
This is an artifact for the CAV'23 tool paper "Kratos2: an SMT-Based Model Checker for Imperative Programs".

For detailed instructions, see the README.md file within the archive.

name: Artifact for CBMC-SSM: Bounded Model Checking of C Programs with Symbolic Shadow Memory
description: Dynamic program analysis tools such as Eraser, Memcheck, or ThreadSanitizer abstract the contents of individual memory locations and store the abstraction results in a separate data structure called shadow memory. They then use this meta-information to efficiently implement the actual analyses. In this paper, we describe the implementation of an efficient symbolic shadow memory extension for the CBMC bounded model checker that can be accessed through an API, and sketch its use in the design o...
keywords: software verification, concurrency, model checking, bug finding

name: Example model of a nuclear I&C logic for NuSMV / nuXmv
description: A simplified, masked example of a nuclear I&C safety system application logic, modeled for both the NuSVM model checker (finite-domain model) and the nuXmv model checker (infinite-domain model). The models are examples of test cases the author used for assessing  the real number math processing capability of nuXmv, by comparing to NuSMV's performance with abstracted math.

name: Model Checking the Information-Flow of Explainability and Privacy Requirements
DGBTechnologies/JANI-GUI: Paper Release
description: JANI GUI for Storm Model Checker

name: Artifact for FM 2023 Paper: SMPT: A Testbed for Reachability Methods in Generalized Petri Nets
description:
This artifact is self-content and permits to use the SMPT model checker. We also provide scripts to analyze the results of the 2022 edition of Model Checking Contest for the reachability category.

SMPT (for Satisfiability Modulo Petri Net) is a model checker for reachability problems in Petri nets. It started as a portfolio of methods to experiment with symbolic model checking, and was designed to be easily extended. Some distinctive features are its ability to benefit from structural reduct...

name: Lunrtick/palchecker: Submission with Bachelor's Project
description: 5 implementations of a Public Announcement Logic Model Checker

for more information.

name: Lambda artefact
description: A virtual machine with the model checker lambda. The password is 'password'.

description: Artifact for ATVA 2024, paper 80: HyperQB: A QBF-Based Bounded Model Checker for Hyperproperties

name: msuperdock/prover: 2022-09-16
description: A simple theorem prover built with Agda.

name: Integrating Arithmetic Reasoning into the Automated Theorem Prover Leo-III
description:
Leo-III is an automated theorem prover for higher-order logic, designed to handle complex mathematical and logical reasoning. It supports higher-order logic (HOL) and is based on paramodulation. Leo-III is built to cooperate with other theorem provers but can also be used as a stand-alone prover. 
This version of Leo-III is based on version v1.7.0 and is the outcome of a bachelor's thesis, which aimed to extend the prover by integrating theory reasoning for arithmetic.

name: A Formalisation of Approximation Fixpoint Theory
description: A formalisation of approximation fixpoint theory in the theorem prover Coq.

name: iProver v3.9 (SMT-COMP 2024)
description:
iProver is a theorem prover for quantified first-order logic with theories.
iProver accepts problems in SMT2 and TPTP formats.

name: The Rocq Prover
description:
Summary of changes
We highlight some of the most impactful changes here:


fixed incorrect guard checking leading to inconsistencies (multiple PRs)


sort polymorphic universe instances should now be written as @{s ; u} instead of @{s | u}


fixed handling of notation variables for ltac2 in notations (i.e. Notation "'foo' x" := ltac2:(...))


Support for refine attribute in Definition


Rocq can be ...

name: The Complex(ity) Landscape of Checking Infinite Descent (Software Artifact)
description:
Accompanying artifact for POPL2024 paper submission, containing the following:


	Extension of the Cyclist automated theorem prover (cyclist-prover.org) by new algorithms for checking the Infinite Descent property.
	Experimental dataset for algorithms checking Infinite Descent.
keywords: Automated Theorem Prover, Cyclic Proof, Infinite Descent

name: gym-saturation: Gymnasium environments for saturation provers
description:
gym-saturation is a collection of Gymnasium environments for reinforcement learning (RL) agents striving to prove theorems. Currently, only theorems written in TPTP library formal language are supported.

There are two environments in gym-saturation: VampireEnv and IProverEnv. VampireEnv is a wrapper around a recent Vampire prover, and IProverEnv relies on an experimental version of iProver.

In contrast to monolithic architecture of a typical Automated Theorem Prover (ATP), gym-saturation gi...

name: Leo-III 1.7.18
description: Leo-III is an automated theorem prover for (polymorphic) higher-order logic which supports all common TPTP dialects, including THF, TFF and FOF as well as their rank-1 polymorphic derivatives. It is based on a paramodulation calculus with ordering constraints and, in tradition of its predecessor LEO-II, heavily relies on cooperation with external (mostly first-order) theorem provers for increased performance. Nevertheless, Leo-III can also be used as a stand-alone prover without employing any...

name: A Case for First-Class Environments (Artifact)
description: This artifact contains the mechanical formalization of the calculi associated with the paper: A Case for First-Class Environments. All of the metatheory has been formalized in Coq theorem prover. The artifact can be either compiled in the pre-built docker image with all the dependencies installed or built from scratch.

name: A Formalisation of Approximation Fixpoint Theory in Coq
description: Approximation Fixpoint Theory (AFT) is an abstract framework based on lattice theory that unifies semantics of different non-monotonic logic. AFT has revealed itself to be applicable in a variety of new domains within knowledge representation. In this work, formalise the key constructions and results of AFT in the Coq theorem prover, together with a case study illustrating its application to propositional logic programming.

name: Cyclone: A Heterogeneous Tool for Checking Infinite Descent (Software Artifact)
description:
Accompanying artifact for TACAS2025 tool paper, containing the following:

Extension of the Cyclist automated theorem prover (cyclist-prover.org) by new algorithms for checking the Infinite Descent property, and integration of a tool, Cyclone, as a backend Infinite Descent check for Cyclist.
Experimental dataset for algorithms checking Infinite Descent.
Docker images with a pre-built version of the extension of Cyclist, for artifact evaluation.

name: Formal Semantics and Formally Verified Validation for Temporal Planning
description: We present a simple and concise semantics for temporal planning. Our semantics are developed and formalised in the logic of the interactive theorem prover Isabelle/HOL. We derive from those semantics a validation algorithm for temporal planning and show, using a formal proof in Isabelle/HOL, that this validation algorithm implements our semantics. We experimentally evaluate our verified validation algorithm and show that it is practical.

name: Algebraic Laws for Feature Models
description: Software Product Lines (SPL) may be adopted by either bootstrapping existing software products into a SPL, or extending an existing SPL to encompass an additional software product. Program refactorings are usually applied for carrying out those tasks. The notion of SPL refactoring is an extension of the traditional definition of refactoring; it involves not only program refactorings, but also Feature Model (FM) refactorings, in order to improve configurability. However, FM refactorings are ha...

name: Leo-III-LP
description: Leo-III is an established, versatile automated theorem prover for (polymorphic) higher-order logic. Leo-III-LP represents a prototype of a version of this prover that offers the capability to fully automatically output proofs verifiable within the Dedukti framework. This upload accompanies the thesis "Computer-Assisted Proof Verification for Higher-Order Automated Reasoning within the Dedukti Framework," authored by Melanie Taprogge and supervised by Prof. Dr. Alexander Steen and Dr. Hab. Fr&...

name: Automated Reasoning in Normative Detachment Structures with Ideal Conditions
description: This archive contains the two programs discussed in the paper as well as the latest distribution of MLeanCoP
keywords: Deontic logic, theorem prover, modal logic, legal texts

name: Tamarin Prover
description: The Tamarin prover is a security protocol verification tool that supports both falsification (attack finding) and unbounded verification (proving) in the symbolic model. Security protocols are specified as multiset rewriting systems and analyzed with respect to temporal first-order properties.

name: Dis/Equality Graphs
description:
E-graphs are a data structure to compactly represent a program space and reason about equality of program terms. E-graphs have been successfully applied to a number of domains, including program optimization and automated theorem proving. In many applications, however, it necessary to reason about disequality of terms, not only about equality. While disequality reasoning can be encoded, direct support for disequalities increases performance and simplifies the metatheory.
In this artifact, w...

name: Implementation of the Approach for Automatic Test Generation for Information-Flow Properties
description:
This data set contains the implementation of the automatic test generation approach for information flow properties based on the KeY theorem prover.

The approach is described in http://dx.doi.org/10.1145/3297280.3297500

Software
---------

The folder "key" contains a modified version of the KeY theorem prover (https://www.key-project.org/) which can generate tests for a specified noninterference property.
Unzip and run 

java -jar KeY.jar

to start KeY.
Check out http://...

name: GenSys-LTL: Infinite State Reactive Synthesis using Logical LTL Games
A Coq proof of the correctness of X25519 in TweetNaCl
description:
Source code for the paper: A Coq proof of the correctness of X25519 in TweetNaCl.

We formally prove that the C implementation of the X25519 key-exchange protocol in the TweetNaCl library is correct. We prove both that it correctly implements the protocol from Bernstein’s 2006 paper, as standardized in RFC 7748, as well as the absence of undefined behavior like arithmetic overflows and array out of bounds errors. We also formally prove, based on the work of Bartzia and Strub, that X2551...

name: Artefact for the scientific article "The Burden of Proof: Automated Tooling for Rapid Iteration on Large Mechanised Proofs"
description:
This file provides instructions for reproducing results from the paper
The Burden of Proof: Automated Tooling for Rapid Iteration on Large Mechanised Proofs.
The paper describes 3 contributions:
1. a report on the experience of proving the large proof of the CXL coherence property
(available at this Github repository).
2. a discussion on the super_sketch tool and its Isabelle/ML implementation
(published in this Zulip thread).
3. our super_fix tool that fixes errors in a .thy file, such...

name: Machine Independent Language formalization and tools
description:
The Machine Independent Language (MIL) captures microarchitectural features such as out-of-order execution. MIL can be used as a form of abstract microcode language, e.g., as a target language for translating Instruction Set Architecture (ISA) instructions, and for reasoning about microarchitectural features that may cause unwanted information flows, e.g., side channels leaking secret information.


We formalize MIL in the HOL4 theorem prover. The formalization includes the in-order and out-o...

name: Implementation of the Combined Approach
description:
This data set contains the implementation of the Combined Approach -- a tool which combines the theorem prover KeY with the static analysis tool JOANA.

In the folder "build" there are two jar files.

- CombinedApproach.jar is the main application that combines KeY and Joana. It works by loading a .joak file which contains the paths to the source code, compiled jar, to KeY and some others which are not always needed. The .joak file also contains the annotation of the high sources an...

name: Artifact for the CAV 2018 Paper: Symbolic Liveness Analysis of Real-World Software
description:
Abstract

Liveness violation bugs are notoriously hard to detect, especially due to the difficulty inherent in applying formal methods to real-world programs. We present a generic and practically useful liveness property which defines a program as being live as long as it will eventually either consume more input or terminate. We show that this property naturally maps to many different kinds of real-world programs.

To demonstrate the usefulness of our liveness property, we also present an al...

name: Artifact for article "Reflections on Termination of Linear Loops"
description: This is the artifact for the CAV 2021 paper, “Reflections on Termination of Linear Loops”. The artifact provided is an OVA virtual machine that can be opened via VirtualBox. The operating system is Ubuntu 18.04 LTS. It contains an installation of the tool as described in the paper, and the benchmark suites we have used to evaluate the tool. It also contains installations of benchexec and ComPACT, Ultimate Automizer, 2LS, CPAchecker for easy reproduction of results in the...

name: Analysis and Integration of Generic Application Framework
description:
This Deliverable is based on the outcomes of task T4.2.2 Generic middleware architecture design and implementation and T4.2.3 Component specification and implementation for application scenarios.

Within WhoLoDancE, several tools have been developed to fulfil the project requirements. Since WhoLoDancE considers several application scenarios, the use of different programming languages, development environments and technologies is mandatory. Nevertheless, in the development process an integrati...

name: Termination Resilience Static Analysis
Proton SV-COMP 2024 Competition Contribution
description: PROTON is a tool for termination and non-termination analysis of software.

name: Decision Tree Learning in CEGIS-Based Termination Analysis
description:
This is a docker image containing a termination analyzer, MuVal [1].

You can load and run the image by the following commands.

sudo docker load -i cav21ae.tar
sudo docker run -it coar:cav21ae_dt /bin/bash --login

See /home/muval/coar/cav21ae_dt/README.md or our github repository for details.

[1] Satoshi Kura, Hiroshi Unno, and Ichiro Hasuo. Decision Tree Learning in CEGIS-Based Termination Analysis. CAV 2021.

name: SAFTerm: A Structural-aware Framework for Termination Analysis via Neural Networks
description: The prototype implementation for paper “SAFTerm: A Structural-aware Framework for Termination Analysis via Neural Networks”.

name: FSE2022benchmarks/termination: FSE2022benchmark-termination
description: Benchmarks and result-files for paper "Large-Scale Analysis of Non-Termination Bugs in Real-World OSS Projects" (FSE-2022)

name: coq-tactician/coq-tactician: Tactician 1.0~beta2~neural+8.11 for Coq 8.11 with modifications for neural networks
description: A Seamless, Interactive Tactic Learner and Prover for Coq

name: coq-tactician/coq-tactician: Tactician 1.0~beta2+8.15 for Coq 8.15
description: A Seamless, Interactive Tactic Learner and Prover for Coq

name: JellePiepenbrock/iprover-gnn-server: v0.1.0-archive
description: A GNN clause selection predictor for the instantion-calculus prover iProver

name: coq-tactician/coq-tactician: Tactician 1.0~beta2+8.11 for Coq 8.11
description: A Seamless, Interactive Tactic Learner and Prover for Coq

name: coq-tactician/coq-tactician: Tactician 1.0~beta2+8.12 for Coq 8.12
description: A Seamless, Interactive Tactic Learner and Prover for Coq

name: BiCoq: Modeling bigraphs with Rocq Prover
description: An implementation of Robin Milner's bigraphs using the Rocq Prover.

name: mtarunpr/coq-prover: Initial release
description: Prove theorems in Coq by extracting lemmas at failure points. Also contains tools for parsing Coq files and fine-tuning LLMs.

name: naveensundarg/prover: november-22-2019
description: No description provided.

name: FSE2022benchmarks/-FSE-2022-Termination: FSE2022-Termination
description: Benchmarks and result-files for paper "Large-Scale Analysis of Non-Termination Bugs in Real-World OSS Projects" (FSE-2022)

name: A Formal Analysis of Apple's iMessage PQ3 Protocol
description: This artifact contains the formal models and proofs of Apple's iMessage PQ3 protocol for the Tamarin prover. It also contains a pseudocode specification of the protocol.

name: Hobbit: Space-Efficient zkSNARK with Optimal Prover Time
description: Implementation of Hobbit. Note that in order to compile it you need to download the C++ implementation of Blake3 hash function.

name: isabelle-prover/isabelle-go-codegen: v0.3.1
description:
Identical code to v0.3.1, but contains a fix to include all files in the Zenodo export.
Release notes for v0.3 follow.
Updated for Isabelle2024.

The code in this repository is now the same state as the AFP entry.
The Dockerfile has been updated to use the Isabelle-bundled Go installer (see also the README).

name: Verified Translation of Guarded Programs
description: Systems based on the Curry-Howard correspondence are rendered unsound by diverging terms; as such, self-referential definitions are typically restricted to ensure termination. For coinductive types, this involves checking productivity, i.e., that any finite prefix of the data can be computed in finite time. Syntactic conditions (such as Rocq's productivity checker) can be used, but are known to reject valid productive definitions.A more flexible approach due to Nakano [2000] is to enforce pro...

name: Looping for Good: Cyclic Proofs for Security Protocols
description: This artifact provides an implementation and examples of a cyclic proof system for the Tamarin Prover, a protocol verifier in the symbolic model. The artifact's top-level README provides installation and general usage instructions.

name: DeepMIP
description: Code for DeepMIP and MiniMIP algorithms.

name: Dataset: Feedforward Neural Network Verification in Isabelle/HOL
keywords: Neural network, Deep Learning, Classification Network, Feedforward Network, Verification, Isabelle/HOL

name: Building Verified Neural Networks for Computer Systems with Ouroboros
description: Neural networks are powerful tools. Applying them in computer systems—operating systems, databases, and networked systems—attracts much attention. However, neural networks are complicated black boxes that may produce unexpected results. To train networks with well-defined behaviors, we introduce ouroboros, a system that constructs verified neural networks for computer systems. Verified neural networks are neural networks that satisfy user-defined safety properties, called specific...

name: Artifact for DNNV: A Framework for Deep Neural Network Verification
description: Despite the large number of sophisticated deep neural network (DNN) verification algorithms, DNN verifier developers, users, and researchers still face several challenges. First, verifier developers must contend with the rapidly changing DNN field to support new DNN operations and property types. Second, verifier users have the burden of selecting a verifier input format to specify their problem. Due to the many input formats, this decision can greatly restrict the verifiers that a user may r...

name: MpBP: Verifying Robustness of Neural Networks with   Multi-path Bound Propagation
description:
Given an input region (often infinite perturbed input set) and a neural network f, bound propagation methods propagate the input region along the neural network to compute a bound function for each neuron, thus the output neuron f. The provable bounds of f are then used to determine whether a misclassification exists in this given input region.

MpBP (Multipath Bound Propagaiton) extends classical bound propagation methods with multiple propagation...
keywords: formal verification, neural networks, bound propagation

name: Artifact: Example Guided Synthesis of Linear Approximations for Neural Network Verification
description: This is the artifact for the paper "Example Guided Synthesis of Linear Approximations for Neural Network Verification" published at CAV 2022. The zip file contains a Readme.txt explaining how to use the artifact, and reproduce our results.

name: Artifact for Paper Scalable Verification of GNN-Based Job Schedulers
description: Please follow the instructions in the readme to replicate the results in the paper.

name: Reducing DNN Properties to Enable Falsification with Adversarial Attacks
description:
This artifact accompanies the paper Reducing DNN Properties to Enable Falsification with Adversarial Attacks.
In this artifact, we provide the benchmarks and scripts for reproducing the results of our study,
and we also provide our tool, DNNF for running falsification methods such as adversarial attacks on DNN property specifications specified using the DNNP language of DNNV.

While many DNN verification techniques have been introduced in the past few years to enable the checking of...

name: Incremental Verification of Neural Networks
description: Complete verification of deep neural networks (DNNs) can exactly determine whether the DNN satisfies a desired trustworthy property (e.g., robustness, fairness) on an infinite set of inputs or not. Despite the tremendous progress to improve the scalability of complete verifiers over the years on individual DNNs, they are inherently inefficient when a deployed DNN is updated to improve its inference speed or accuracy. The inefficiency is because the expensive verifier needs to be run from scra...

name: Specification and Verification of DNN Properties with Domain-Specific Semantics
description:
DSS ARTIFACT

This repository can be used to explore all facets of our study, including reproducing the results in two different ways: reproduction with pre-computed data (faster and good to check the overall results) or full-reproduction (slow and good to check intermediate pipeline results). We now provide details on the content of the artifact and instructions on its installation and usage.

name: CAN-Verify Artifacts
description:
This zenodo link is the repository for the automated tool CAN-Verify to streamlined the entire underlying process of formal modelling/encoding from BDI agents in CAN language to Bigraphs, model execution in BigraphER tool, and back-end model-checker with PRISM.

The detailed installation and usage of this tool (and the reproduction of the examples) can be found in README.md.

Any question do not hesitate to drop an email to mengwei.xu@manchester.ac.uk

name: Modelling the Turtle Python library in CSP
description:
Software verification is an important tool in establishing the reliability of critical systems. One
potential area of application is in the field of robotics, as robots take on more tasks in both day-to-
day areas and highly specialised domains. Robots are usually given a plan to follow, if there are
errors in this plan it will have negative consequences for the robot’s performance. The capability
to check plans for errors in advance could prevent this. Python is a popular programming l...

name: Robustness Testing of Software Verifiers
description:
This artifact contains the implementation and data used for the experimental
evaluation of "Robustness Testing of Software Verifiers". This includes
the tool "semtransforms" which implements the all semantics-preserving
transformations proposed in our work. In addition,the preprocessed benchmarks
used for evaluating the robustness of software verifiers are also available.
All generated robustness tests are based on the ReachSafety-Loops category of the SV-COMP 2023.

name: Solver GFT
description: This repository contains all the resources and artifacts that support the GFT solver as a plugin in [Flama](https://flamapy.github.io/).

name: Diver: Oracle-Guided SMT Solver Testing with Unrestricted Random Mutations
description:
Diver is a black-box fuzzer for testing SMT Solvers. The technical details of Diver can be found in our paper accepted to ICSE 2023: "Diver: Oracle-Guided SMT Solver Testing with Unrestricted Random Mutations"

The artifact is also provided in the Github repository: https://github.com/kupl/Diver-Artifact

name: QSOLE: Automated QBF Equivalence Checking
description:
QSOLE: Automatic QBF Equivalence Checking
Introduction
This artifact was submitted by Peter Pfeiffer, Mark Peyrer, Daniel Große and Martina Seidl for the TACAS 2026 with the submission number 9062 aiming for Available, Functional and Reusable badges. It contains everything necessary to reproduce the examples shown in the corresponding paper alongside testcases to demonstrate basic functionality. In the following sections you will learn everything you need to know about this artifact and...

name: Code to replicate "Accounting for surge dynamics is key to modeling tropical cyclone-induced coastal flooding"
description:
Code to replicate the results (including data preprocessing, analysis, evaluation and plots) of Vogt et al. 2023 (submitted).
The main part of the code is contained in evaluation.zip along with a comprehensive README file with information about how to install, how to obtain the necessary input data, and how to run the scripts.
The files tc_inundation.zip and climada_petals.zip contain scripts to compute inundated areas from IBTrACS tropical cyclone track data, using the geophysical flow solve...

name: Design and implementation of QASP Solver
description: We present, a new ASP solver called Quantifying over ASP, or briefly QASP, for ASP(Q) problems resolution, i.e. an extensive ASP formalism, inspired by Quantified Boolean Formula, which adds quantifiers over stable models, in order to model PSPACE problem.

name: Skolem CPOG Projected Knowledge Compilation Verifier
description:
This code supports the generation and certification of the projected knowledge compilation of a Boolean formula.  
This repository accompanies the paper "Certified Projected Knowledge Compilation" by Randal E. Bryant, Yong Kiam Tan, and Marijn J. H. Heule, to be published at the 2025 Conference on the Theory and Applications of SAT Testing (SAT).
It contains the following programs

A version of the D4 knowledge compiler modified to generate Skolem assignments to the quantified variables
...

name: Verifying OR-of-ANDs is equivalent to NAND-of-NANDs using SMT solvers
description:
Jupyter notebook to showcase the use of SMT solvers to formalize and verify that an OR-of-ANDs boolean formula can be represented using only NAND gates.
GitHub link: NAND.ipynb

name: Practical Approximate Quantifier Elimination for Non-linear Real Arithmetic (artefact)
Coq formalization of QRC1
description:
This is a Coq formalization of the QRC1 quantified modal logic introduced in Quantified Reflection Calculus with one modality and further studied in An Escape from Vardanyan’s Theorem. Part of the Coq formalization is described in Towards a Coq formalization of a quantified modal logic.

v1.0.0 includes:


	the syntax of quantified and strictly positive formulas
	the notion of QRC1 proof
	a proof that it is possible to conservatively add extra constants to the langua...

name: Boolean condition coverage with evaluation trees
description:
This is an instance of the LabPal experimental environment. It contains experiments aimed at comparing a new technique for Boolean test input generation to existing tools and algorithms. The artifact has been accepted as complementary material for the paper entitled Test Suite Generation for Boolean Conditions with Equivalence Class Partitioning, published at the FormaliSE 2022 conference.

Context

Consider a Boolean expression φ formed of the traditional connectives ∧ ("an...

name: Nemo: A Tool to Transform Feature Models with Numerical Features and Arithmetic Constraints
description:
This is a pre-print, please access and cite the published version:

https://doi.org/10.1007/978-3-031-08129-3_4

Real-world Software Product Lines (SPLs) need Numerical Feature Models (NFMs) whose features not only have boolean values satisfying boolean constraints, but also have numeric attributes satisfying arithmetic constraints. A key operation on NFMs finds near-optimal performing products, which requires counting the number of SPL products. Typical constraint satisfaction solvers perfor...

description:

https://youtu.be/V-ONW8PftwM

A key operation on NFMs finds near-optimal performing products, which requires counting th...
